content.description:
Just to the left of

Quarter Inch Master

, this is a V4 arete highball, that is quinessential Hartman's.
content.location:
Near the top of Kill Hill a few hundred yards southwest of the parking lot, just left of

Quarter Inch Master

, the thin finger crack.

content.description: Thin finger crack with a couple hand jams. Definitely one of the best crack, boulder problems in the Valley.
content.location: Near the top of Kill Hill a few hundred yards southwest of the parking lot.

content.description: Stand start with a hand on the rounded bump with a crimp on it (at about 7 feet) and pinching the arete.  Move up the arete on crimps and slopers to apex of the nose and 'beach whale mantle' yourself to the top.  Really good.
content.protection: Pads, spotter.  There is a back-breaking boulder in the landing zone, so have an attentive spotter.
content.location:
This is on the same formation as

Quarter Inch Master

but on the opposite end.  The arete that looks like a shark's head from the west.  It is hard to miss.

content.description:
This is the sds for

Jaws Arete

. It adds 4 BURLY moves to the stand start.  Start in an obvious sit start on the arete on good holds, make long moves to crimps and an even longer cross move to a pinch on the arete, match on the bump (stand start hold), and finish out the stand start.
content.location:
This is at the opposite end of the formation from

Quarter Inch Master

.

content.description: It's a boulder start with a touch of friction for feet. You get a couple of good fingers in the thin part down low and then you go to a hand jam which is followed up with some more good jams. Once you get that 1st jam, it's cake from there.
content.protection: I guess if you wanted to, you could rope up and place pro in this thing. No anchors at the top.
content.location:
It's on the Quarter Inch Master Area on the West side. (Just to the left of

Raleigh Arete

.)
